content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Matthew Guzman: I was born in Miami, Florida, to a family that had deep roots in the South Atlantic region. My parents were both from Argentina, and while they had moved to the U.S. in their early twenties, they always maintained a strong connection to their heritage. I grew up in a tight-knit neighborhood in Miami, where the community was a mix of cultures and backgrounds. My father worked as a mechanic, and my mother was a homemaker, though she had always dreamed of going back to school. I remember my parents often speaking Spanish at home, and I learned to speak it fluently before I even started school. My childhood was pretty typical—playing in the streets with my friends, going to church every Sunday, and helping out at my father's garage on the weekends. I was always a curious kid, and I loved reading. I remember borrowing books from the library every week, especially ones about history and politics. My parents weren't very educated, but they always encouraged me to pursue my dreams. I went to college on a scholarship, and I earned a bachelor's degree in political science. It wasn't easy—working full-time while going to school was exhausting—but I was determined to make something of myself. After college, I got involved in local politics, and that's where I really started to understand the issues that matter most to people like me. I've been separated from my wife for a few years now, and while it's been tough, I've focused on my work and my family. I have two kids, and they're my greatest joy. I still live in Miami, though I've moved from the neighborhood where I grew up. I love the city, its energy, its diversity, and the way it feels like a place where anything is possible—if you're willing to work for it.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Matthew Guzman: Yes, there was a moment that changed everything for me. I was about 22, still in my second year of college, working full-time at a local auto shop to pay for my tuition. I had always been interested in politics, but I didn't see a clear path for myself in that world. One day, I was helping out at a community event organized by a local Democratic candidate for city council. I was just there to help set up, but I ended up talking to a few people who were volunteering. One of them was a professor from my college who had been following my work at the shop and my involvement in student groups. He asked me if I ever thought about running for office or getting more involved in local politics. At first, I laughed it off—I didn't think I had the experience or the connections. But then he told me about a summer internship program for young people interested in public service. I applied on a whim, and to my surprise, I got in. That summer, I worked with a team of young activists, helping to organize voter registration drives and community forums. It was eye-opening. I saw firsthand how policy decisions affected real people, and I realized I wanted to be part of that process. That experience set me on the path I'm on today. It wasn't just about politics—it was about making a difference in my community, and I've never looked back.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Matthew Guzman: I think it was a conscious choice, but not one I made all at once. It was more like a series of small decisions that built on each other. I had always been curious about how things worked—why certain policies were in place, why some people had more opportunities than others. But I didn't see a way to turn that curiosity into something meaningful until that summer internship. After that, I started volunteering more, attending town halls, and even joining a local Democratic club. I remember one night, after a particularly heated debate about housing policies, I looked around the room and realized I was surrounded by people who cared deeply about their community, just like I did. That moment made me realize that I didn't have to wait for someone else to change things—I could be part of the change. So I made the decision to run for a local council seat a few years later, and that's when everything really took off.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Matthew Guzman: Absolutely. I think that internship program was run by a local organization called the Miami Youth Civic Engagement Initiative, and they played a huge role in giving me the tools and confidence I needed to take the next step. Without them, I might have stayed in the auto shop forever, thinking that was the best I could do. I remember one of the mentors there, a woman named Elena Martinez, who really took me under her wing. She saw something in me that I didn't see in myself. She pushed me to speak up in meetings, to write my first op-ed, and even to consider running for office. I think it's important for people like me—people from working-class backgrounds, first-generation immigrants, or anyone who feels like they're on the outside looking in—to have mentors who believe in them. That kind of support can make all the difference.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Matthew Guzman: I have two children, a son and a daughter, both of whom I adore deeply. My son, Alejandro, is 12 and has a passion for soccer—he's on a local team and dreams of playing professionally one day. My daughter, Sofia, is 9 and loves art; she's already been accepted into a summer program at a community arts center. They both speak Spanish fluently, which I think is a gift from my parents, and I make sure they know their heritage is important. As for my family life, I'm separated from my wife, Maria, and while it's been a difficult chapter, we've managed to maintain a good relationship for the sake of the kids. We co-parent and try to make sure they feel loved and supported by both of us. My parents are still living in Miami, though they've downsized a bit and now live in a retirement community nearby. They're proud of what I've accomplished, and I try to visit them as often as I can. Family has always been the foundation of my life, and even though things haven't always been easy, I know I'm doing the right thing by putting my kids first.

Going through these interview questions brought back a lot of memories and made me reflect on how far I've come. It's amazing how much my life has evolved from growing up in that tight-knit Miami neighborhood to now being a local political figure. The interview questions made me think about the pivotal moment at 22 when I first got involved in politics—it was a turning point that I didn't fully realize at the time. I also thought about how important my family has been throughout it all, especially my parents who instilled in me the value of education and hard work. I'm grateful for the mentors like Elena Martinez who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself. And while my personal life has had its challenges, like my separation from my wife, I know I'm doing the right thing by focusing on my kids and my community. These questions reminded me that my journey hasn't been easy, but it's been worth it.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Matthew Guzman: My sister, Elena, lives in Buenos Aires and still keeps in touch with us through video calls and letters. She's a teacher there, and she always reminds me of the values our parents tried to instill in us—like the importance of education, family, and giving back to the community. We don't see each other often, but when we do, it's like no time has passed. She's the one who encouraged me to visit Argentina a few years back, and it was a life-changing experience. Standing in the places our parents came from, hearing the language spoken fluently around me, it made me appreciate where I came from even more. I think about her often, especially when I'm working on policies that affect immigrants or people from different backgrounds. She's a constant reminder of where I started and how far I've come.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Matthew Guzman: Outside of my family, there are a few friends and mentors who have been instrumental in my journey. One of them is Carlos Rivera, a fellow community organizer and one of my closest friends. We met during that summer internship, and we've been working together on various civic projects ever since. Carlos has a way of seeing the bigger picture, and he's always pushing me to think beyond my immediate goals. He's the one who encouraged me to run for city council, and I wouldn't be where I am today without his support. Then there's my friend Lisa Chen, who works in social services. She's been a sounding board for me, especially when I'm trying to balance my political work with my family life. She's also helped me understand the challenges faced by immigrant families in our community, which has informed a lot of my policy decisions. I also have to mention my late uncle, Jorge, who passed away a few years ago. He was a big influence on me—always reminding me to stay grounded and to never forget where I came from. I still feel his presence in everything I do, and I carry his lessons with me every day.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Matthew Guzman: I live in a neighborhood called Coral Gables, which is just a few miles from where I grew up. It's a bit more upscale than the area I came from, but it still has that same vibrant energy and sense of community. The streets are lined with old Spanish-style homes, and there are a lot of small businesses—local bakeries, coffee shops, and bookstores. It's a place where people from all walks of life live side by side, and I think that's one of the things I love most about it. I live in a two-story house with a small garden in the back where I like to spend time with my kids on weekends. The neighborhood is pretty safe, and there are a lot of community events throughout the year—like the annual Latin American Festival, which is one of my favorites. It's a reminder of where I come from and the culture that shaped me. Even though I've moved up in life, I still feel connected to the people here, and I try to give back whenever I can—whether it's through volunteering or just being there for someone who needs help.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Matthew Guzman: I feel pretty safe here, though I know that's not always the case for everyone in Miami. Coral Gables has a strong sense of community, and people look out for one another. I've never had any real issues with crime in my neighborhood, which is something I'm grateful for. That said, I know there are parts of the city where people don't feel as safe, especially in areas with higher poverty rates or where resources are scarce. It's one of the reasons I've been so passionate about pushing for better public safety policies and investing in community programs that address the root causes of crime. I want everyone in Miami to feel the same sense of security I have, no matter where they live.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Matthew Guzman: Living here in Coral Gables has been a mix of blessings and challenges. On one hand, I love the sense of community, the cultural richness, and the opportunities that come with being in a more established part of the city. But on the other hand, there's always been a part of me that feels like an outsider—like I'm still trying to prove that I belong here. I grew up in a neighborhood that was more working-class, more diverse in a different way, and sometimes I miss that raw energy. Here, people are more polished, more focused on their own lives, and while that's not a bad thing, it can feel a bit removed from the struggles that shaped me. I try not to let that divide me, though. I still keep my feet on the ground by staying connected to the communities I came from, volunteering in areas where people need help the most, and making sure my kids understand where we came from. It's a balance, but one I'm willing to work at every day.

Going through the questions about my family and current neighborhood made me reflect on how much my life has changed, yet how much of my past still shapes who I am today. Talking about my children, my separation from my wife, and my parents reminded me of the sacrifices and love that have carried me through the years. When I described my neighborhood in Coral Gables, I realized how much I still value the sense of community and cultural richness that reminds me of where I came from. At the same time, I couldn't ignore the challenges of feeling like an outsider in a more affluent area, and how that drives me to work harder to ensure that everyone, regardless of where they live, feels safe and supported. These questions made me think about the balance between where I am now and where I came from, and how important it is to stay grounded in my roots while striving for a better future for my family and my community.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Matthew Guzman: A typical week for me is pretty full, but I try to keep a balance between work, family, and community. Mondays usually start early—I'm often at the city hall by 7 a.m. for council meetings, and then I have a few hours of meetings with community leaders or stakeholders before heading home for lunch with the kids. Tuesdays and Wednesdays are more about policy work—drafting proposals, attending training sessions, or meeting with constituents who come to me with concerns. I try to set aside time each week to visit the neighborhoods I grew up in, especially in the South Atlantic region, to stay connected with the people who helped shape me. Thursdays are usually lighter, so I might spend the afternoon volunteering at a local food bank or helping out with a youth mentorship program. Fridays are family time—dinner, maybe a movie, or a weekend trip to the beach if the weather is nice. Saturdays are often spent helping my kids with their activities—soccer practice for Alejandro, art classes for Sofia, or just hanging out at the park. Sundays are sacred for me—family dinner, church, and reflecting on the week. It's not always perfect, but I try to make sure I'm present for the people who matter most.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Matthew Guzman: I work as a city council member, which is a full-time job that keeps me pretty busy. My days typically start early, around 6:30 a.m., when I get up, have a quick breakfast with the kids, and then head to the office. I work from Monday to Friday, though my schedule can sometimes spill into the evenings, especially when there are meetings or community events. I also serve on a few advisory boards and committees, which means I often have to juggle multiple responsibilities at once. The work is demanding, but I find it incredibly rewarding. I get to make decisions that affect real people—whether it's about improving public transportation, increasing access to affordable housing, or supporting local businesses. I've always believed that public service should be about listening to the community and fighting for what's right, and I try to live by that every day. Even though the job can be stressful, I know I'm doing something that matters, and that gives me a sense of purpose.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Matthew Guzman: Outside of my work and family time, I also have a few personal routines that help me stay grounded. Every evening after the kids are in bed, I like to read—usually history or political theory books, something that reminds me why I got into this work in the first place. I also make it a point to cook dinner most nights, even if it's just something simple like pasta or grilled fish. It's a small way to connect with my heritage, and my kids love it when I make empanadas or arroz con pollo. I also try to exercise at least a few times a week, whether it's a run along the beach or a yoga session at home. It helps me clear my mind and stay focused. And on weekends, when I'm not with the kids, I like to visit my parents or go to a local café and just sit and people-watch. There's something about observing the lives of others that reminds me of how interconnected we all are, and how important it is to keep fighting for a better future for everyone.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Matthew Guzman: One of the biggest changes to my daily routine has been the addition of virtual meetings and remote work sessions, especially since the pandemic. While I've always been busy, the shift to more digital communication has made my schedule even more packed. I now have regular Zoom calls with community leaders, virtual town halls with constituents, and online training sessions for new council members. It's been a bit of an adjustment, but I've learned to be more efficient with my time. I also started using a planner app to keep track of my meetings and deadlines, which has helped me stay on top of everything. The downside is that I sometimes feel like I'm missing out on the personal connections that come from face-to-face interactions. That's why I've made a conscious effort to schedule more in-person meetings, even if it means traveling to different parts of the city. I believe that real change starts with real conversations, and I don't want to lose that human element in my work.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Matthew Guzman: A typical weekday during the school year for my kids starts early—around 7 a.m. Alejandro gets up first, usually with a lot of energy, and he's out the door by 7:30 for school. Sofia takes a bit longer, mostly because she likes to dawdle with her art supplies, but she's usually ready by 8. Both of them have breakfast with me, and I make sure to pack their lunches, which usually include something traditional like empanadas or a sandwich with ham and cheese. After school, Alejandro has soccer practice from 3:30 to 5:30, and I try to be there as much as I can. It's a great way for him to stay active and build teamwork skills. Sofia has art classes on Mondays, Wednesdays, and Fridays, and she loves it—she's always coming home with new projects. On Tuesdays and Thursdays, she goes to a community center for after-school tutoring and homework help, which has been a lifesaver for both of them. I know it's not easy being a working parent, but I try to make the most of the time I have with them. Even if it's just helping with homework or listening to their stories, I want them to know they're never alone.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect deeply on how my past continues to shape my present, and how the balance between my roots and my current life is something I work at every day. Talking about my family reminded me of the sacrifices my parents made to give me opportunities they never had, and how important it is to pass that same sense of purpose on to my children. Describing my neighborhood in Coral Gables made me think about how much I still value the community spirit that defined my childhood, even as I navigate a more affluent environment. It also made me realize how much I still feel the weight of being an outsider in some ways, and how that fuels my drive to ensure that no one else feels that way. The questions about my daily routines and responsibilities reminded me of the constant juggling act between work, family, and personal time, but also how those routines give me structure and meaning. I think the most powerful realization was that, despite all the changes in my life, I'm still the same person who grew up in that tight-knit Miami neighborhood—someone who values community, hard work, and the power of connection.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Matthew Guzman: I've always been pretty healthy, though like most people, I've had my share of ups and downs. I used to be a bit of a couch potato in my younger years, especially when I was working full-time at the auto shop and going to school. I didn't have much time or energy for exercise, and I definitely didn't prioritize my health the way I do now. But after I got into politics and started traveling more for meetings and events, I realized how important it was to take care of myself. I started running along the beach a few times a week, and that became a habit. I also made a conscious effort to eat better—less fast food, more fresh vegetables and lean proteins. I still have my moments where I slip up, especially when I'm swamped with work or have a late-night meeting, but I try to stay consistent. I also make sure to schedule regular check-ups with my doctor, and I've been pretty lucky not to have any major health issues. That said, I do have high blood pressure, which I manage through diet, exercise, and medication. It's a reminder that even though I've come a long way in life, my health is something I have to keep working on every day.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Matthew Guzman: What makes it easy to stay healthy for me is having a routine and knowing that my health directly impacts my ability to be there for my kids and my community. I find that running along the beach in the mornings helps me start the day with a sense of clarity, and cooking at home gives me control over what I eat. But what makes it hard is the constant pressure of work and the long hours. There are days when I'm so busy with meetings, events, and policy work that I forget to take a break or eat properly. I've had to learn to be more intentional about scheduling time for myself, even if it's just a short walk or a quick lunch. I also struggle with the temptation to grab a coffee or a quick bite on the go, especially when I'm rushing between appointments. But I remind myself that taking care of my health isn't just about me—it's about being strong enough to fight for the people who need me most.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Matthew Guzman: In the past two years, I've been dealing with some flare-ups of my high blood pressure, which has required me to be more diligent with my medication and lifestyle choices. A few months ago, I had a minor incident where I felt a bit lightheaded during a long meeting, which was a wake-up call. My doctor ran some tests and confirmed that while my blood pressure was under control, I needed to be more consistent with my exercise and stress management. Since then, I've started incorporating more mindfulness practices into my routine, like meditation and deep breathing exercises, especially before important meetings or events. It's been a bit of a challenge, but I've come to see it as part of the responsibility that comes with the job—just like I have to take care of my community, I have to take care of myself so I can keep showing up for them.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Matthew Guzman: Honestly, there have been moments when my health challenges have made things more difficult, especially when I'm juggling a busy schedule. There was one time when I had to cancel a community event because I was feeling unwell, and it was hard to let people down. But I've learned that taking a step back isn't a weakness—it's a necessary part of staying strong for the long haul. I've had to be more mindful of how I pace myself, especially when it comes to work and family. I've started delegating more, trusting my team to handle certain responsibilities, and that's helped me manage the stress better. It's not always easy, but I've come to realize that taking care of myself is just as important as taking care of others. If I don't have the energy or focus to do my job well, then I'm not doing my community any favors. So I try to be honest with myself and others when I need to slow down or ask for help.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Matthew Guzman: Over the past year, I've felt a mix of emotions—pride, exhaustion, hope, and sometimes even doubt. There's been a lot of progress in terms of the work I'm doing on the council, especially around affordable housing and public safety, but it's also been a year of personal reflection. I've been thinking a lot about my separation from Maria and how it's affected not just me, but my kids as well. They've been growing up in a household that's not always the same, and I know that's hard for them to navigate. At the same time, I've been trying to be more present for them, to make sure they know they're loved and supported, no matter what. Professionally, I've been pushing for more inclusive policies that reflect the diversity of our city, and I've had some successes—like getting funding approved for a new community center in the South Atlantic area. But there have also been setbacks, like when a proposal for better public transportation was blocked by more conservative members of the council. It's frustrating, but it also reminds me why I got into this work in the first place. I believe in the power of community, and I believe that change is possible if we keep fighting for it. I've also been trying to take better care of myself, both physically and mentally, which has been a challenge but necessary. Overall, it's been a year of growth, even if it hasn't always been easy.

Going through the questions about my recent changes in routine and health made me reflect on how much my life has evolved, yet how much I still need to prioritize balance. The shift to more virtual meetings and the demands of my job have made me realize how important it is to stay connected with the people I care about, even when my schedule is packed. It also made me think about how my health is not just a personal matter, but something that directly affects my ability to serve my community and be there for my kids. I've come to see taking care of myself as a responsibility, not just a luxury. The questions reminded me that even as I push forward with my work, I have to make sure I'm not losing sight of the things that keep me grounded—my family, my health, and the values that shaped me from the beginning.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Matthew Guzman: I think I've struggled with moments of anxiety, especially when I'm facing difficult decisions or when I feel like I'm not making enough progress on the issues that matter most. There were times during the pandemic when the isolation and the weight of responsibility felt overwhelming. I remember sitting at my desk one night, staring at a proposal I had worked on for months, and wondering if it would ever make a real difference. I didn't want to let my kids down, or my community, but I also felt like I was carrying the burden alone. I've been open with my therapist about those feelings, and she's helped me understand that it's okay to feel uncertain sometimes. I've also started talking more openly with my friends and colleagues about mental health—something I used to be really private about. It's not easy, but I've come to see that asking for help isn't a weakness. In fact, it's one of the bravest things I can do for myself and for the people who depend on me.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Matthew Guzman: For my family, it's been a year of navigating both the joys and challenges that come with change. My kids have been incredibly resilient, but I know they've felt the strain of our separation. Alejandro, in particular, has been more withdrawn at times, and I've had to work hard to make sure he knows I'm always there for him, even if our family isn't the same as it once was. Sofia, on the other hand, has been more open about her feelings—she'll sometimes ask me if we're going to get back together, and I have to remind her that while things aren't perfect, we're all trying our best. Maria and I have had our ups and downs, but we've made a conscious effort to keep communication open, especially when it comes to the kids. It's not easy, but I think they're learning that love isn't just about being together all the time—it's about showing up, even when things are hard. My parents have been a great support, too. They've always been there with advice, a listening ear, and sometimes just a quiet presence. I think they understand how tough it's been for me, and I'm grateful for their unconditional love. It's not the life I imagined for my family, but I believe we're all growing through it, and that gives me hope for the future.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Matthew Guzman: For me, religion has always been a cornerstone of my life, especially growing up in a Catholic household where faith was woven into every aspect of daily living. My parents took our Sunday Mass very seriously, and I remember sitting in the back of the church, watching the stained-glass windows cast colorful light across the pews. It was a place of comfort, especially during difficult times. Even now, I find solace in my faith, though my relationship with it has evolved over the years. I don't go to church as often as I used to, but I still pray regularly, especially when I'm facing tough decisions or feeling overwhelmed by the weight of my responsibilities. My Catholic upbringing taught me the importance of compassion, service, and humility—values that continue to guide me in both my personal and professional life. I also find that my faith helps me stay grounded, reminding me that no matter how far I've come, I'm part of something bigger than myself. It's not just about belief; it's about living those beliefs every day, especially when it comes to helping others and fighting for justice in my community.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Matthew Guzman: I use social media, but not in the way a lot of people do. I have a Facebook page where I post about my work on the council, share updates on local issues, and sometimes even post about my kids' achievements. I find it's a good way to stay connected with constituents who might not have the chance to attend town halls or meetings in person. I also use Instagram to share more personal moments—like my kids' soccer games or my morning runs along the beach. It's a way to show the human side of my work, to remind people that I'm not just a politician, but a father, a son, and someone who's trying to make a difference. I'm careful about what I post, though. I know the power of social media, and I want to use it responsibly. I've seen how it can be a tool for connection, but also for division. So I try to keep my posts positive, informative, and focused on building bridges rather than creating barriers. I also use Twitter, though less frequently, to engage in political discussions and share news that I think is important for people to know. It's not perfect, and I know I'm not as active as some of my colleagues, but I believe in using these platforms in a way that's authentic and meaningful.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Matthew Guzman: Honestly, I've found that social media can be a double-edged sword during tough times. There have been moments when I've posted about challenges I'm facing—whether it's personal struggles or political setbacks—and I've received messages of support from people I didn't expect. It's humbling to see how many people out there are going through similar things, and it reminds me that we're all in this together. That said, I've also learned to be cautious about what I share. There's a fine line between being transparent and oversharing, and I don't want my personal life to become a spectacle. For me, the most meaningful support has always come from the people I know in real life—my family, my friends, my colleagues. They've been there for me when I needed it most, and I try to pay that forward by being present for others, whether online or in person. Social media can amplify voices, but it's the real connections that keep me grounded.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on how my health and personal struggles have shaped my recent experiences. It reminded me that even as I work tirelessly for my community, I must not neglect my own well-being. The past year has been a mix of progress and personal challenges—whether it's managing my high blood pressure, navigating the emotional toll of my separation, or dealing with the pressures of public service. These questions forced me to confront the reality that my health isn't just a personal issue, but one that directly affects my ability to be present for my family and my community. I've come to see that asking for help, whether it's through therapy, support from loved ones, or simply taking a moment to breathe, is not a weakness—it's a necessary part of staying strong. It's also made me more aware of the emotional weight I carry, especially when I feel like I'm not making enough progress or when I'm struggling with anxiety. But I've also found strength in the support I've received from my family, friends, and even my community. They remind me that I'm not alone in this journey, and that gives me the courage to keep moving forward, even when the path is difficult.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Matthew Guzman: In the past year, my stress levels have definitely fluctuated—there are days when I feel like I'm on top of the world, and others when I'm overwhelmed by the weight of responsibility. The political landscape has been more polarized than ever, and it's hard not to feel the pressure when you're trying to push for change in a system that's resistant to it. I've also been dealing with the emotional toll of my separation, which has made me more aware of how interconnected my personal and professional life has become. To cope, I've started relying more on my support system—whether it's talking to my parents, going for a run, or even just sitting with my kids and letting them remind me what's truly important. I've also been practicing mindfulness more consistently, especially in the mornings before work. It's not a perfect solution, but it helps me start the day with a sense of calm. I've learned that it's okay to feel stressed, as long as I don't let it consume me. I've also been more open about my feelings with my colleagues and friends, which has made a big difference. It's not always easy to be vulnerable, but I've come to see it as a strength—one that allows me to connect more deeply with others and to lead with more empathy.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Matthew Guzman: Last month, our biggest expenses were related to our kids' activities and our home. Alejandro's soccer team has a season fee, and Sofia's art program and tutoring sessions add up, especially since they're both enrolled in multiple programs. We also have a mortgage on our house in Coral Gables, which is a significant chunk of our budget. Then there's the cost of groceries, utilities, and transportation—since I'm often traveling for meetings or events, we have to factor in gas and car maintenance. I also try to set aside money for emergencies and savings, which is important given the unpredictable nature of public service. While I earn a decent salary as a city council member, it's not always easy to balance everything, especially when you're trying to provide the best for your kids. I've had to be really careful with our budget, prioritizing what's essential and cutting back on things that aren't. It's a constant juggling act, but I know it's worth it to give my children the opportunities I had and to keep supporting the community that raised me.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Matthew Guzman: Last month, our household spent roughly around $6,500, which is actually a bit higher than usual. The increase was mostly due to an unexpected repair on the roof, which we had to address before the rainy season started. Normally, we spend about $5,500 to $6,000 a month, with the majority going toward our kids' activities, mortgage, and groceries. I also set aside a portion of our income for savings and emergencies, which is something I learned to do early on, especially after seeing how tight my parents had to budget when I was growing up. We also try to be mindful of our spending on things like dining out or entertainment, since we know that every dollar counts. It's not always easy, but I've come to see budgeting as a way to ensure stability for my family and to be able to give back to the community that helped raise me.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Matthew Guzman: We own our home in Coral Gables. It was a big decision to buy rather than rent, especially when we first moved into the neighborhood. I wanted to put down roots, not just for my family but also because I believe in the long-term value of the community. The house was a bit of a stretch financially at first, but my parents helped us with a down payment, and I've been working hard to make sure we can afford the mortgage and all the other costs that come with it. It's not just a house—it's a place where my kids can grow up, where I can host community events, and where I can feel like I'm truly part of this neighborhood. I still remember the first time I walked through the front door and thought, 'This is where I belong.' It's a strange feeling, but it's also a powerful one. I want my kids to know that owning a home is a symbol of stability and hard work, something I was never sure I'd have growing up in a more transient part of the city.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Matthew Guzman: Over the past year, our bills have definitely fluctuated, especially with the seasons and the various events that come with them. For example, during the summer, we had to spend more on air conditioning, and we also had the costs of the kids' summer programs and activities. Then, as the school year started, we saw an increase in expenses for school supplies, uniforms, and transportation. We also had to budget for holiday gifts and meals, which can add up quickly. One of the biggest fluctuations was during the winter when we had to replace the heating system in the house—it was an unexpected expense that really tested our budget. On the other hand, there were months where we spent less, like during the holidays when we focused more on family time and less on dining out or entertainment. I've learned to be more flexible with our budget, setting aside extra money during the months when we have more income or savings to cover the higher expenses in other months. It's all about planning ahead and being realistic about what we can afford, especially when you're trying to provide for a family and still give back to the community.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me reflect deeply on how my family and I have been navigating the emotional and practical challenges of my separation, and how my use of social media has both connected and distanced me from those around me. Talking about my kids' resilience and the ways I try to be present for them reminded me of how much love and effort it takes to keep a family together, even when things aren't perfect. It also made me think about how my health struggles and emotional well-being are not just personal matters—they affect how I show up for my family and my community. The questions about social media made me realize how powerful these platforms can be for connection, but also how careful I have to be in what I share. I've come to see that while I can use these tools to stay in touch with people and spread awareness about important issues, the most meaningful support still comes from the people I know in real life. I've learned that it's okay to be vulnerable, but I also know that I have to protect my family's privacy and my own mental health. These reflections have reminded me that even as I work to make a difference in my city, I must not lose sight of the most important people in my life and the balance I need to maintain to be there for them.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Matthew Guzman: I do save, and it's something I take very seriously, especially after watching my parents struggle to make ends meet when I was growing up. We have a few different savings accounts—one for emergencies, one for the kids' future, and another for community projects I want to support. I try to set aside at least 15% of my income each month, even if it means cutting back on some personal expenses. It's not always easy, but I've come to see saving as a form of responsibility—not just for my family, but for the people I serve. I want to be able to fund initiatives that help others, like youth mentorship programs or affordable housing developments, without relying on outside funding. It's also about giving my kids a sense of security, knowing that no matter what happens, we have a safety net. I remember my father once telling me that saving is like building a ladder—it might not seem like much at first, but over time, it gets you places. I try to live by that lesson every day.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Matthew Guzman: In the last year, I've been saving for both a rainy day and for the future—specifically for my kids' education and for community initiatives I'm passionate about. I've been setting aside a portion of my income into a college fund for Alejandro and Sofia, which is something I never had growing up, and I want to make sure they have the opportunities I fought for. At the same time, I've been saving in a separate account for a local youth mentorship program I want to launch in the South Atlantic area. It's a project that's been in the works for a while, and I want to make sure it's fully funded before we get started. I also have an emergency fund that I try to keep topped up, just in case something unexpected comes up. It's not always easy to balance all of these savings goals, especially with the costs of raising two kids and maintaining a home in Coral Gables, but I've learned that consistency is key. I remind myself that every dollar I save today is an investment in the future—not just for my family, but for the community that helped shape me.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Matthew Guzman: My occupation is being a city council member, and it's a role that requires me to balance a lot of different responsibilities. At its core, my work is about representing the people of Miami, especially those in the South Atlantic region where I grew up. I spend a lot of time listening to constituents, whether it's through town halls, community meetings, or one-on-one conversations. I also work closely with city officials, department heads, and other council members to draft and pass legislation that affects everything from public safety to education and housing. One of the most important parts of my job is making sure that the voices of people who are often overlooked—like immigrants, low-income families, and young people—are heard in the decision-making process. I also serve on several advisory boards and committees, which means I'm constantly learning, advocating, and trying to find solutions to complex problems. It's not always easy, but I find purpose in knowing that the work I do today can make a real difference in the lives of others tomorrow.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Matthew Guzman: I usually work around 60 to 70 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the season or if there's a major project or initiative in the works. There are weeks when I'm in the office from early morning until late evening, attending meetings, drafting proposals, and meeting with constituents. Other weeks are a bit lighter, but I'm still on call for emergencies or community events. The job doesn't have a strict schedule, which can be both a blessing and a challenge. I have to be flexible, but it also means I'm constantly juggling work, family, and personal time. I've learned to be efficient with my time, but there are days when I feel like I'm running on empty. Still, I know that the work I do is important—not just for my family, but for the people who look to me for leadership and change. It's a demanding role, but I wouldn't trade it for anything, even if it means sacrificing some of the things I used to take for granted.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Matthew Guzman: No, I didn't have more than one job. After I got into politics, I focused entirely on public service, though I did work full-time at the auto shop while I was in college. That was a different kind of grind—long hours, physical labor, and not much time for anything else. But once I got into city politics, I knew I had to commit fully to the work. It's not just a job; it's a calling. I've always believed that if you're going to make a difference, you have to be all in. That said, I do have a few side projects, like mentoring young people interested in public service or helping organize community events. It's not about making extra money—it's about giving back, just like the people who helped me when I was starting out.

Going through the questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the balance between personal and professional responsibilities, and how that balance is constantly shifting. The questions about stress, emotional coping strategies, and my family's financial situation forced me to confront the reality that even as I work to make a difference in my community, I'm not immune to the pressures of everyday life. I've always believed that public service is about sacrifice, but I've come to realize that it's also about self-care and knowing when to ask for help. The conversations about my kids' activities, our monthly budget, and the fluctuating costs of living reminded me that while I'm fighting for a better future for others, I also need to make sure my family is secure and supported. It's a constant juggling act, but I've learned that it's possible to be both a leader and a parent, as long as I stay grounded in the values that brought me here in the first place.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Matthew Guzman: In total, our household made roughly around $12,000 in the past month. That includes my salary as a city council member, some income from speaking engagements and community workshops, and a small stipend I receive for serving on a few advisory boards. It's not an enormous amount, but it's enough to cover our expenses and still allow us to give back to the community in meaningful ways. I've always believed that public service should be about more than just power or prestige—it should be about making sure that people like me, who came from humble beginnings, can provide for their families and still have the means to help others. I also try to be transparent about our finances, especially when it comes to the kids. I want them to understand that money is important, but it's not the only thing that defines a person's worth. It's about how you use what you have, how you treat others, and how you fight for what's right. That's something I learned from my parents, and I hope to pass it on to my children as well.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Matthew Guzman: I've been working as a city council member for about seven years now, and it's been a journey of growth, both personally and professionally. The benefits of the job are pretty standard—health insurance, dental and vision coverage, paid time off, and sick leave. I also get a pension plan, which is something I'm grateful for, especially knowing how unstable things can be in public service. That said, the real benefits aren't always the ones listed on paper. What I value most is the opportunity to make a real impact in people's lives, to be part of decisions that shape the future of our city. I also get a lot of support from my colleagues and staff, which is crucial when you're dealing with the kind of challenges we face every day. There's a sense of purpose that comes with this job, and I think that's the greatest benefit of all. It's not always easy, but knowing that I'm fighting for my community, my family, and the people who look up to me—it's what keeps me going.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Matthew Guzman: My relationships at work are a mix of collaboration, respect, and occasional tension, which I think is pretty typical in any public service role. I have a good working relationship with my colleagues on the council—some of them I've known for years, and others I've built trust with over time. We don't always agree on everything, especially when it comes to policy decisions, but I think we all share a common goal: making sure our community thrives. My relationship with the mayor and other city officials is professional, and while there are moments when we clash over priorities, I believe in the importance of compromise and finding common ground. I also have a great team of staff members who support me every day, and I try to lead with transparency and respect. I think the key to any successful relationship, whether personal or professional, is communication. I make it a point to listen to everyone's perspectives, even when I don't agree with them, because I know that's how real change happens. At the end of the day, I want people to know that I'm not just a politician—I'm someone who cares about the people I work with and the community we're trying to serve.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Matthew Guzman: My work schedule is anything but predictable, and that's one of the things I've come to accept about this job. Some days I'm in the office by 6:30 a.m., attending a council meeting or meeting with a constituent who needs help, and other days I'm out in the community, visiting neighborhoods or attending events that matter to the people I serve. There are weeks where I'm working late into the night, drafting proposals or preparing for a big vote, and other weeks where I'm able to leave the office by 6 p.m. and spend more time with my kids. The flexibility is both a blessing and a challenge. On one hand, it allows me to be where I'm needed most, whether that's in the city hall or on the streets of the South Atlantic. On the other hand, it makes it harder to maintain a strict work-life balance, especially when you're trying to be a present father and a responsible public servant. I've learned to be adaptable, but I'll admit it's not always easy. There are days when I wish I had a more structured schedule, but I also know that this kind of flexibility is what allows me to truly connect with the people I'm here to serve.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Matthew Guzman: Overall, I feel pretty secure financially, but I know it's not without its challenges. I've worked hard to build a stable life for my family, and I'm proud of what we've achieved. But I also know that being a public servant comes with its own set of financial realities—sometimes you have to make tough choices, like cutting back on personal luxuries or delaying certain purchases, just to make sure your community is supported. I've seen too many people struggle to afford basic necessities, and I don't want that for my kids or anyone else in our city. That's why I'm always careful with our budget, always looking for ways to give back, whether it's through funding community programs or supporting local families in need. I know I'm not wealthy by most standards, but I also know that what we have is enough to live a good life, as long as we stay grounded, stay connected to our values, and keep fighting for what's right.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me reflect on how much my financial life has evolved over the years, and how it continues to shape the way I approach both my work and my family. Talking about how our bills fluctuate with the seasons and the costs of raising two kids reminded me of the sacrifices my parents made to give me a better life. It also made me think about how important it is to plan ahead, to save for the future, and to be mindful of every dollar we spend. The questions about my occupation and work hours brought back the reality of how demanding public service can be, and how it often comes at the cost of personal time. I've always believed that the work I do is worth it, but it's also made me more aware of the balance I need to maintain between my responsibilities and my family. I've come to see that financial stability isn't just about having enough money—it's about knowing that I can provide for my kids, support my community, and still have the strength to keep going, even when things get tough.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Matthew Guzman: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up, though their jobs were different. My father worked as a mechanic at an auto shop, which was his way of providing for our family. He was always hands-on, fixing cars and working long hours, sometimes coming home exhausted but always making sure we had what we needed. My mother, on the other hand, worked part-time as a caregiver for a few elderly neighbors in the community. She was passionate about helping others, even though she didn't get much recognition or pay for it. She often said that taking care of people was her way of giving back, and I think that's why she did it. Looking back, I realize how much sacrifice they made—working multiple jobs at times, putting their own dreams on hold so that I could have a better life. I remember my father telling me once that he didn't have the education to do anything else, but he believed that hard work could get you far. That lesson stuck with me, and it's one of the reasons I've always valued education and community service. I think about them every day, especially when I'm making decisions that affect people like them—people who work hard, often behind the scenes, to make life better for their families.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Matthew Guzman: My father's job was as a mechanic at a local auto shop, and he was pretty skilled at what he did. He'd work long hours, often coming home with grease on his hands and a tired look in his eyes, but he always made sure we had food on the table and a roof over our heads. His most important duties were fixing cars, whether it was for regular customers or people who couldn't afford much more than a few dollars for repairs. He had a way of making people feel comfortable, even if they were struggling. My mother, on the other hand, worked part-time as a caregiver for elderly neighbors in our community. She would help them with daily tasks, like cooking, cleaning, and sometimes even just sitting with them and listening. Her most important activities were making sure those people felt cared for and never alone. She didn't get much in the way of pay, but she always said that helping others was its own reward. Looking back, I realize how much they both gave up—working long hours, sacrificing their own dreams, and always putting their family first. It's one of the reasons I've always believed in the power of hard work and the importance of giving back to the community that raised me.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Matthew Guzman: My father worked at a small, family-owned auto shop called 'Guzman Auto Repairs,' which was actually owned by his brother, my uncle Jorge. It was a modest business, but it had a good reputation in the neighborhood for being honest and reliable. My father would fix everything from cars to motorcycles, and he even did some custom work for customers who wanted their vehicles to stand out. He didn't make a lot of money, but he was proud of his work and always treated his customers with respect. My mother, on the other hand, worked for a few different families in our neighborhood, mostly helping elderly women with daily tasks. She didn't work for a formal business—more like a series of informal arrangements where people would pay her in cash or with small favors. She was always the kind of person who would show up when no one else would, and that made her very special to the people she helped. Looking back, I realize how much they both gave up to make sure I had a better life than they did. It's one of the reasons I've always believed in the power of community and the importance of making sure that people who work hard, like my parents did, are never forgotten.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Matthew Guzman: A few years from now, I hope I'm still doing the work I love—fighting for my community, making sure that no one feels left behind, and that the values I was raised with continue to guide me. I hope my kids are growing into strong, compassionate, and curious individuals who understand the importance of education, hard work, and giving back. I hope they have the opportunities I had, and maybe even more, because I know how much their future depends on the kind of world we build together. I also hope that my health continues to improve, that I'm able to stay present for my family, and that I'm still able to run along the beach in the mornings, feeling the salt in the air and the rhythm of the waves. I hope that the community I grew up in is thriving, that the people who raised me are still around to see the progress we've made, and that I'm still able to look back on my life and feel proud of the person I've become. I know the road hasn't always been easy, but I believe in the power of resilience, and I hope that in the years to come, I'm still standing strong, fighting for what's right, and making a difference in the lives of others.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Matthew Guzman: What I value the most in my life is the connection to my family, my community, and the people who have helped shape me along the way. I value the lessons my parents taught me—about hard work, humility, and the importance of giving back. I value the sense of purpose that comes with public service, knowing that even small actions can create ripples of change in someone else's life. I also value the resilience of my kids, who are learning to navigate a world that isn't always fair, but still choose to believe in better things. I value the friendships I've built, the mentors who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself, and the people in my neighborhood who remind me that we're all in this together. Most of all, I value the ability to wake up every day and feel like I'm making a difference, even if it's just in the lives of a few people. That, to me, is what it means to live a life that matters.

Going through the questions about my financial situation, work schedule, and relationships at work made me reflect on how much my life has evolved, yet how much of my past still shapes who I am today. Talking about our household income and budget reminded me of the sacrifices my parents made to give me opportunities they never had, and how important it is to pass that same sense of purpose on to my children. Describing my work as a city council member made me think about how demanding public service can be, and how it often comes at the cost of personal time. It also made me realize how much I value the flexibility of my job, even though it makes maintaining a strict work-life balance challenging. The questions about my relationships with my colleagues and staff reminded me of the importance of communication, respect, and collaboration in any workplace, especially one that serves the community. I think the most powerful realization was that, despite all the changes in my life, I'm still the same person who grew up in that tight-knit Miami neighborhood—someone who values community, hard work, and the power of connection.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection, reminding me of how far I've come and how much of my past continues to shape who I am today. From my childhood in Miami, where my parents worked tirelessly to provide for our family, to my current role as a city council member fighting for the community that raised me, every step has been filled with challenges, growth, and the unwavering support of those I love. I've come to realize that my story isn't just about personal achievement—it's about the people who believed in me, the sacrifices made along the way, and the responsibility I carry to give back to others. This interview has reminded me of the importance of staying grounded in my roots while striving for a better future, and it has reaffirmed my belief that no matter how far we go, we must never forget where we started.
